channel.title: Video card outputting wrong mode?
channel.description: Sometimes my computer boots fine, but other times the monitor wont turn on because apparently the video card isn't outputting the signal in an unsupported mode. Whats odd is that if I detach the dvi cable and turn the computer on and off, then reattach the cable, I can get the monitor working again. I looked at the settings in windows and currently the monitor is set at 1280 x 1024 at 60hz and im 99999% positive this mode is supported. But it seems like this error occurs outside of windows because the screen is blank even when the computer is booting. I tried to look for some setting in the bios but there is none. Please help?

item.title: Video card outputting wrong mode?
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

Boot into safe mode(so it’s set at 800x600, lowest and works on all monitors, or should…), and set it to your desired resolution.

Hope that works, it does for me :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.title: Video card outputting wrong mode?
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

seems to be a dvi problem perhaps with the graphics card bios

Read full topic

item.title: Video card outputting wrong mode?
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

every fifth or so boot with my computer, ever since I put the ati card in, the screen randomly chops in half and put the top bit on the bottom, I solve this by turning the screen off and on.

Read full topic

item.title: Video card outputting wrong mode?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:286514”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=378917.msg2850226#msg2850226 date=1246494706]

What about turning the monitor off and back on after the computer is already on, does that fix it?

I had this problem with an ATI Graphics Card. Is your monitor perhaps made by Acer? Even if not, use a dvi to vga converter and the problem should disappear

But then you lose some quality.
[/quote]I can’t see the difference between VGA and DVI.

My monitor with DVI looks a lot sharper than with VGA. Could be specific to the monitor I suppose.[/quote]probably, because on my Acer 1916 (budget-monitor) it doesn’t make a difference.

Read full topic

My monitor with DVI looks a lot sharper than with VGA. Could be specific to the monitor I suppose.

What about turning the monitor off and back on after the computer is already on, does that fix it?

Speljohan:

I had this problem with an ATI Graphics Card. Is your monitor perhaps made by Acer? Even if not, use a dvi to vga converter and the problem should disappear

But then you lose some quality.
